lines.text: it is dearness alone that gives every thing its value. Heaven knows how to put a proper price upon its goods; and it would be strange indeed if so celestial an article as FREEDOM should not be highly rated.' George Washington November 10, 1777
Connie, why didn't you tell me about this letter from the bank?
I didn't want to bother you, Bill.
Bother me? It's just a letter about foreclosure, that's all.
It's Saturday afternoon. I'm taking you for a drive in the country.
A drive? What do I want to drive in the country for? It's full of insects.
Darling, are you alright?
Oh, fine. Fine.
[looks around]
Well, at least nothing can happen for ANOTHER 17 years.
[Both Bill and Connie fall into a boarded up well, followed by a big splash]

[looking inside]
Mr. and Mrs. Fuller struck water! WHOOPIIIIEEEE!
When George Washington slept here, where did he hang his clothes? There isn't a closet in there. And apparently, he never had to go to the bathroom.
Y'know, I nearly killed Pop once. They stopped me just in time. I was only a kid then.
They should've put you in an electric highchair. Sit down, ya' rat!

[hanging from a tree branch]
Hey Uncle Bill, look at me, I'm Tarzan the apeman!
[singing]
Look at me, up in a tree!
Right where he belongs.
This must be why people drink, it makes them feel better.

I can just see myself ending my days here. I can hear them say, 'There's the old Fuller's place up the road. Ever meet old man Fuller? He's a HERMIT! Don't let your children go near him, he'll eat their arms off!'
[suddenly falls into an old, boarded-up well]

[stomping up the stairs]
Is it safe to walk up this thing in September, or must I install a ski lift?
Ain't had a good snowstorm in about... three years.

You just wait until you see it a month from now when it's fixed up. We're going to do it all with local labor. Aren't we, Mr. Kimber? Mr. Kimber's going to superintend the whole thing. Can't you just see the possibilities?
Connie, I don't see how you do it... or WHY!

[singing after taking a drink of cider]
I'll never smiiille agaain until I smile at you.
You know what that dame told me? "George Washington slept here."
Yeah? I guess that's what drove them to Valley Forge.
George Washington shoulda' chopped this house down instead of the cherry tree!
Look at this place! Just LOOK at it!
But, it was a terrific bargain, Bill. I got it as a terrific bargain.

[in mock disbelief]
MORE than a dollar?

[stepping off a train with a box of gardening supplies]
Got my hands full, Sam. I'll tip you tomorrow.

[watching Bill walk away]
Same thing everyday.
Mr. Fuller, every time you open the screen door, some flies get in.
Oh, so it's MY fault for coming into the house!
Well, it'd be better if you didn't.
I see...
Darling, what's the matter with your head.
There's nothing the matter with MY head, Connie. I'm holding it because it's the only head left in the family.
Bill! Why don't we invite Mr. Kimber? After all, it's HIS cider.
Well, sure!
[calling out the window]
HEY, MR. KIIMBEER! MR. HIII-HO KIMBEERRR!
Please say you're not angry.
Angry? I could spit from here to Mt. Vernon.

[to Uncle Stanley at dinner table]
Boy, if you didn't have money, you'd be in trouble with those stories.
Connie, I don't know how you do it... or why.
